threads.com:
Let's talk about hardware: anyone thinking to upgrade their rig over the holidays? I've been playing with the idea, and i realized i don't really know what an ideal artists computer looks like. >What is more important, CPU or GPU?
>How much RAM do you really need?
>Do you have a special storage setup? Do you use NVME SSDs?

Then i realized that upgrading my monitor is probably one of the more impactful upgrades i can make.
>What resolution monitor do you use?
>Does your monitor have a low delta-E? (i eventually found that this is apparently what matters, not srgb coverage)
>have you ever used unusual formats (ultrawide, portrait etc) how does it feel to use them?

Right now i'm mainly looking for a 27" monitor that is accurate and at least 1440p. But feel free to discuss anything hardware-art related. Also interested if anyone here draws/paints on an ultrawide. I like the idea of it, if not the price.

Also post your specs if you want to.

(of course there is also tablet talk, but let's leave that to >>>/dtg/)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>Athlon X4 845
>32GB DDR3
>Radeon Pro wx7100 + wx4100
>DELL e2216h and Viewsonic VG2239m
>Huion WH1409
I built this a few years back and it has been treating me well since. Each GPU runs its own monitor, and since they both have hardware encoding, so I use the wx4100 to record while I draw to take load off of my wx7100. I put a lighter weight Linux distro on it, so it runs well despite the CPU being low end.
Overall the system is nice and stable, and I can draw nicely on it. I have a traditional sketching set up in addition to my computer, so I don't lack tools for learning the craft.

I don't have the funds to upgrade, since a significant upgrade would mean replacing much of the computer, since it's so outdated.

Definitely drawn pixel by pixel. This stuff is from the 90's. Vector art software didn't exist at the time and if you zoom in you can see that diagonal lines don't share a third pixel when going diagonally so someone went and drew the contour pixel by pixel. You can try doing this in Graphics Gale and it's actually lots of fun but doing a full 640x800 illustration takes a while.

threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6381095
>>6381092
Looking at your reference, you might notice that the treeline in the background looks blueshifted and quite desaturated compared to the foliage in the middle distance. In the meantime, the reflected foliage on the water's surface has less of this variation, but is far more blurry in the background than the foreground. Watercolour is a medium I admit I am terrible with (oils are my preferred medium) but I would suggest that if you want to make the trees in the background not blend into the middle distance you should make them less saturated, maybe use lighter washes or even lay down an EXTREMELY thin glaze of payne's grey before painting them in. Your trees in the middle distance should instead use more saturated and slightly warmer mixes of the colours used on the background.
Your eye picked this up for your water reflections and that made the two groups of trees look distinct as reflected in the water, but your colours were too close on the trees themselves. You also blended quite a few of the yellows from the sky into your background trees, which makes them read as bright, and we tend to read brighter things as closer.

I still really like the piece anon, I would happily send a postcard with that on it. The inside of the boats are my favourite part of it, the colour in those read beautifully, along with the slate roof and reflected lights on the water. We're all gonna make it.

ok, vectors are lines made through math rather than a stamp, they scale and never pixelate either zooming in or out.

csp has fantastic tools for vector lines, what all line art should be, if you use a tablet.

affinity, if you use vectors by putting points down and manually adjusting lines with a mouse has a far better system for line weight with a mouse.

I cant really say it much simpler than that, look up vector tools on youtube for csp and designer.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6381538
csp you are able to draw a vector with a tablet, it will more or less auto gen the points, and you can come in later to edit the vector with a raster tool, it has tools that takes points away, and that you can quickly make the line thinner without redrawing the same line and hopefully getting it correct 50 times.

when I do line art, I typically use vectors just so if I ever do need to make it bigger its far more versatile than raster, and the fact the tools work almost the same as raster tools if you don't go into all the various subtools for the vector means its kind of hard to argue a reason not to use them.

If you have csp, try out its vector tools, they are fantastic.

It has been 5 months or 6 since AI became a thing in everyone's mouth with DALL-E mini and personally (as someone who consooms art and is not an artist) I haven't noticed a lot of changes in the art community, even when AIs like StableDiffusion have fixed most of its problems in less than 2 months.
Every artist I follow keeps receiving commissions and closing in minutes, they keep earning thousands on Patreon and the engagement has been pretty much the same as how things were a year ago, if not better.
I have noticed most artists I follow started to only post their work on Twitter while abandoning pages like Pixiv, FurAffinity, eHentai and other ones we all know due to the immense amount of spam that's in there, heck, even I as a consoomer I stopped using Pixiv, it became an unsearchble sea of untagged mess and I can't fucking jerk off anymore without digging like crazy for 5+ minutes in order to find the shit I actually like and not a sea of deformed victorian smug sluts.

If you ask me I feel AI is not going to affect freelancing in a lot of ways, however, when it comes to work in the industry I can say I've already seen some changes, like the use of AI for voice acting or AI used to design prints for shirts to be massproduced.
How do you see things? We're close to the end of the year.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
When drawing by reference should I keep the ref on the same screen, side by side with my drawing, or put it on a different screen?
I feel like it's easier to draw when they're side by side, but I don't know if easier means I'm learning faster or I'm learning less.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6380882
side by side is definitely easier as you can match the reference and your own drawing in size, it's also easier to make direct measurements using horizontal lines to see if everything lines up identically.

the further away from side by side like on a separate monitor then it feels more like drawing from life, like if the image is max size on your other screen you'll have to draw it smaller to fit on your canvas so you'll do manual measurements and guidelines

both work, but side by side is the easiest if you're focusing on pure accuracy.

Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

Hello beg. Today i had a revelation. While i was copying gesture / sketch from this old master called Delacroix i wondered why ALL THREE art books i have been through included such simple crude sketches from him (while he made mighty grand stuff) and put it on full page as the best piece ever (while showing way more complex and better pieces in smaller areas). And while i was copying it i realized the grand truth of gesture. When master does gesture, it floats, it moves, it uses minimum amount of strokes to tell as much as possible, it even exaggerates the object.

I am so pitiful beg in comparison all my 3050 gestures i made so far are utterly shit and broken. They arent drawings. They arent even diagrams. They are broken diagrams. The only saving grace is that the time wasnt complete waste. I wouldnt understand this without the prior grind. When i first saw Delacroix sketches in KtD or DoRSoB i only saw curious scribbles. I think i now understand why people can point out when some drawing was made by tracing photo or model. Its stiff, lifeless, a diagram.

Now all whats left is to figure out how to actually apply any of this into actual drawing process. To draw more than what i just observe. Or how to observe the reference on deeper level. Begtard /blog

Unironically, copy the homework but make slight changes.
Draw what you see in the ref, but add something different at a few parts.
For example, tilt the head or use different hand gestures.
Use additional refs if you have trouble imagining something not in the original ref.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6377712
>copying I don't learn.
ngmi

I've learned more from studying refs, watching artists draw live on Twitch and imitating them and following along timelapse videos on YouTube at 0.5x speed than from reading 10 books or just making shit up as I go.

The point is to actually integrate what you're learning into your next work. For example: say you want to study a really cool photo ref that you like. You do the thing, and notice while drawing it that you need to solve a certain amount of problems using the tools at your disposal to get the result you like.

Then, next time when you're drawing another thing (another study, or your own thing, or a commission, or just something fun) you apply the same logic that you did when you copied the thing.

It's about building an arsenal of technical and practical knowledge and honing it to the edge, and then using that to your advantage in order to exploit your own imagination.

In my opinion, creativity without technical prowess is pretty pictures.

Creativity with technical prowess is sublime.

threads.com:
I think I have found a solution to the AI problem, or at least a potentially beneficial application of AI to protect artists that are unwilling to have their intellectual property abused for AI training.
AI proponents usually argue that "styles can't be copywritten!", and that gives them every right to train your art style with AI models. This is true, but it is incredibly subjective for a human to determine where one person's style ends and where another person's style begins. Legally, this murkiness makes it difficult to properly defend an artist's artstyle.
But as we have seen, AIs have no trouble understanding what an artist's distinctive 'style' is. An AI can clearly differentiate between two different styles, and can mathematically determine the difference between them. Since AI doesn't actually create its own unique art styles, but just meshes them together, an AI could also determine what percentage of an image is generated using copywritten material.
With this logic, why shouldn't we push for AI-assisted copyright protections on artstyles to defend artistic copyright from AI scrapers?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6380491
It's a print made from an engraving. You start with a copper (or wood) plate and carve into it with cutting tools. This results in very sharp details and finer control. You can then use this plate to transfer the drawing onto paper with ink. As you can see from this picture, you can get really fine details. Much finer than what you could get inking straight onto paper by hand.

https://www.metmuseum.org/about-the-met/collection-areas/drawings-and-prints/materials-and-techniques/printmaking/engraving

You have to use a decent amount of force to mark the copper, so a lot of control is required. Since the tools naturally carve a guide for them to follow, so in some ways it is a bit easier to control. If you make a mistake, you can't really fix it so you have to be extra careful. Rulers, compasses and guides are used, but the masters could do it freehand.

>Is it as slow and deliberate and time consuming as I would imagine?
Yeah, pretty much.

Franklin Booth didn't know the illustrations he saw were made from engravings, but he managed to recreate the effect using only pen and ink. So with a great deal of practice, it's certainly possible achieve similar results by hand.

threads.com: Why does my digital art have absolutely 0 soul compared to my trad art? I feel like it doesn't even exist, like it's some file in my pc not art. And the tablet has this plastic texture feel to it. How the fuck do you produce anything of value in those conditions?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6378983
Just tried this, it’s subtle, but it does just enough to help it feel more sovlful, this anon speaks wisdom

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6378176
It's 2 things.

1. texture. The standard brushes for digital art don't have any texture to them that makes them look too smooth and unnatural. Either use textured brushes or draw in the texture with different hatching methods. I personally don't use the paper texture method anon above said, but I don't see anything wrong with it.

2. Color mixing. Colors in digital don't mix as easily as traditional and tend to push things towards gray which isn't true of real life pigments. To solve this, it's important to remember to build up your colors in layers (not actual layers, but like painting a base color and then painting on top of that) so that the underlying pigments come through, this is true of trad art, but doubly so for good appealism in digital.

last_replies.com:
>>6379333
Since you are actually willing to accept criticism and want to know more, I will admit it was harsh statement at first. By flats, I literally mean flats. Colors. Not the dimensionality of the image. You put flats down, then come in with more with digital rendering. Yours looked like simple flat colors with no gradients or change in colors beyond what the ink provided. The image itself has perspective and does lead you to the back a bit with the road and shrinking trees, etc.

However, the linework fails you. It is rushed, even if this likely took you a long time. Take our pine trees on the left. You literally scribble left and right without even apparently taking the pen off the page. The branches also have dimensionality and arent left-right only, yet all the lines scream left-right and, while I said flats related to the colors only, this actually flattens those trees on the page when examined closely. There should be different clusters of needles depending on if the branch is coming at us, going away, angled one way or another. The lighting would reflect this and provide differing levels of black - not uniform back and forth lines. The far left tree is also broken. The very bottom goes up and then you can see the tree is off after the first wave of black scribbles - the trunk is literally not connected to the stump. A tree in background to the righ tof this has same effect, though could literally be broken and angled, but unlikely. I'm not sure how you did this. Like youd have underdrawing in pencil and do the trunk and pine needles/leaves over top or at same time. the through line of the trunk should be the same and not break liek this.

Another issue is simple anatomy. Yes, trees have anatomy. Branches do not get thicker as they go up. You can have branches and lumps at times where branches didnt form/broke, but generally branches get thinner as they go out and as they go higher on the trunk.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6379333
>>6379414
(cont)
The far right tree, for example, has its far right branch get massively bigger than the main brach off the trunk. This branch cannot support that weight. There are minor examples of real life trees getting these large growths, but the physical sub branch isnt going to be liek double the thickness of the main branch off the trunk. The trunk that split off and goes highest on the same tree is massively thicker than it could possibly get. It is almost identical to the bottom base of the trunk where it should be thickest. The weight would topple the tree when factoring in how much higher it goes.

For leaves on this and other leaf trees, the squiggle effect is common for filling in trees, but this is way too haphazard. it reads as a mess. the line weights dont imply anything. while common to not put stems and tiny branches for this type of inking, many float in space and just look like random swirls with no leaf implied at any point. much of hte center and right side read like you just wanted this done as fast as possible after doing all the trunks. whether it took forever or not, these pieces typically take days. yes, days. if i was to draw this piece, map it out and begin inking, it owuld take me probably 10-20 hours depending on size of image and level fo detail i wanted. Thats a minimum estimate. Inking one square inch of something this intricate can take literal hours. You probably did this in afternoon.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6379333
>>6379414
>>6379427
Ive posted a few examples of trees with inking focus. Different styles and ways of rendering. Even the most simplified rendering shows attention to detail in their lines. The pines arent scribbled. The leaves arent just random swirls. They have line weights and contrasts. Light isnt uniform thorughout a tree and entire piece either (yours is all from the right and never reflects how other trees or the tree itself should affect lighting). These arent meant to be do it like this either or be this good right now. Just examples for future reference and to show the difference in controlled lines that you htought about vs 'get it done' mentality.

Also note some of these how dark it gets vs use of light. Yours is relatively uniform - black trunks, light leaves, very dark pines. Basically doing edge work. Take the first image - the black trunks in foreground really draw the eye. THe very light center line. The second image is similar - the very dark rendering of shadows dilineated from the rendering of bark. You can tell the bark is dark, but the shadows really pop. Value studies are very important when planning out ink. Ive done literal horus of inking and then realized ive overinked or the values are just fucked and had to start over. Thats before even considering bad lines or anything. Just clearly see value problems. Yours is relatively uniform blacks across. If you are intending to color, this isnt necessarily bad i guess, but for an inked piece, you wont have colors to save the values/it isnt just line art type of deal.

I recommend trying to do just a single branch or replicate a style you want - literally save it, fade it out or blue line it and print it off. Ink the blue lined art of said piece. Try to see the line he made and make it - its likely not just a random line thrown without thought.

last_replies.com:
>>6379333
>>6379414
>>6379427
>>6379441
This is an inked piece thats probably in line with what you were attempting. It is relatively simple with weak line work. Cabin not particularly good. But the piece comes together with lines. Youll see different renderings of even the simple background trees/trunks. They arent all identical in left to right values. Theres variety. The grass and brush is just thrown lines and some implied flowers or whatever with circles, etc. But the lines arent just up and down/all angled one way. There's values between the lines in some cases.

Compare some of this amateur piece to yours - even with how rushed this example looks, consider how their tall grass looks to yours. Both are very similar pieces thematically. Scribbles and simplified inking. I believe this is the effect you were going for, but you arent even taking the time this guy did. The lines on yours scream you just scribbled upa nd down in many places. With more care, you can achieve similar effects even 'rushing' like this final example has.

Inking is meticulous and time consuming work. Shortcuts are easily apparent on anyone taking a close examination of it and with any knowledge of the medium. We also see and appreciate that level of effort put in. We see a section of grass and know you spent like 5 hours doing it. We know that tree took you all day. We know the piece took you days to complete. We also know when it took you an hour.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6373619
This challenge is impossible, but this is a very interesting prompt as-is. Images related, seeds pulled out of thin air, custom model mix.

The current generation of tooling is entirely unsuitable to the challenge using txt2img alone. The extensive details you've specified can not be reasonably prompted into existence at once. Such an image could be recreated slowly and carefully through extensive detailed inpainting and ain't nobody got time for that shit.

The current generation of tooling is entirely unsuitable to use your text as a prompt. CLIP has the attention span of a toddler and only speaks in positives. That one sentence about her skin color alone becomes unparsable nonsense. We're just as likely to see cream and chocolate in the image than we are to have it get the correct skin color outside of "brown" ... and if you looked at the entirely not random not cherrypicked pics here, well, there's no brown skin to be seen. Only one tried to get the hair color right. None got the two layers of shirt thing and the heart shaped locket. One decided that your mention of bra was more important than the shirts. Only one actually tried to do something with the strawberry.

If I cared enough, I could probably AND together your description with some magic words and get images that are closer to your goal, but my inpainting game is awful and thus doing it right would be a waste of everyone's time.

I'm a big fan and a big advocate for this technology. I think it's neato. I've visually expressed myself through this tool more, and more effectively, than I've been able to express myself visually through my previous 42 years. But right now it's a toy. It's really fun to play with.

Both advocates and critics need to understand the limitations of the current technology. I'm not sure if whatever anon you were talking to before was trolling you or was a true believer, but you need to know the difficulty level here.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
If you want to learn to make comics then no course will be more valuable than just diving in and making comics on your own. There's no such thing as "comics writing", it's just writing like anything else. Drawing experience has nothing to do with having attended drawing classes. Pick up your pencil and start drawing. Doesn't matter what. Get your practice if you want to draw comics. Get used to the idea of drawing a lot, because that's what comics involve: a LOT of drawing.

Anyway I'd argue a comic book course is a waste of time. There's no value in such a thing, so do something, anything, else. Again, if you're interested in making comics, then just start. Don't waste your time with a course on it, because it will teach you nothing you couldn't have learnt on your own. You can get 100% of the value you would have gotten from the class by sitting outside the lecture hall drawing comics then approaching the students as they finish the class to meet people.

last_replies.com: Been using Affinity products for my graphic design work almost exclusively for 3 years, if you are considering APhoto for art; first download the trial and check the brush tools and panel, it feels very different than Photoshop's and it is more limited; also, the transformation tools work a little bit different and they are not consolidated in the same tool (like in PS's ctrl+t), it's an excellent program and I recommend it but you should try it first to see if there is nothing deal breaking about it. For example, up until the release of v2 a week ago, APhoto was a no-go for making mockups, but now they incorporated nondestructive transformations.

last_replies.com:
I've been drawing for 15 years and every new illustration I make I struggle with the eyes, because I have never settled for a single style.

There are many good-looking ones, but I don't necessarily feel the urge to copy any of them.

Most of the time I just draw a curve for the upper lid and a solid black dot for the iris, making everyone look chinky.

My favorite type, however, is no doubt pic related; characters who keep their eyes closed are always the best.
